subcategory: Non-serious Attitude during Mandatory DEI Training Sessions

content.text: This refers to the challenge that employees do not take DEI trainings seriously when it is made mandatory by their organization.
DEI trainings are not considered important by employees.
Some employees have a misogynist way of thinking. People do not take soft skills training, like diversity training, seriously.
Companies often arrange training sessions to cover legal requirements and force employees to attend them.
Training is often used in reaction to complaints such as harassment cases.
There are limited good quality DEI trainers available.
Ensure or promote visible as well as active participation of senior leadership in the DEI trainings.
Organizations should develop surveys and feedback forms for employees to evaluate the effectiveness of training and its impact on individual development.
Organizations need to offer voluntary diversity training instead of making trainings mandatory for all employees.
Assessment tools such as pretests can be used to make prospective trainees aware of the need for their training.
Organizations can incentivize training, learning and behavioral change as a result of training.
